dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, welcome back to the pod! So, um, on paper, it's looking like a pretty quiet week for market news, right? But underneath, man, things are anything but calm.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Alright, welcome back to the pod! So, um, on paper, it's looking like a pretty quiet week for market news, right? But underneath, man, things are anything but calm.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Its a big week for the market with a host of major companies set to report earnings as stocks pare back from near-record highs on rising concerns over the severity and economic impact of the deadly Chinese coronavirus.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, totally. I mean, we're seeing stocks at near-record highs, which is kind of wild, especially with the, uh, coronavirus still making headlines. But it seems like the impact is actually lessening.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, totally. I mean, we're seeing stocks at near-record highs, which is kind of wild, especially with the, uh, coronavirus still making headlines. But it seems like the impact is actually lessening.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: stocks pare back from near-record highs on rising concerns over the severity and economic impact of the deadly Chinese coronavirus.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? And it's a huge earnings week – Apple, Starbucks, Facebook, Amazon, Tesla, all reporting. I mean, you’d think the virus would dominate the conversation, but these earnings are really stealing the show.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? And it's a huge earnings week - Apple, Starbucks, Facebook, Amazon, Tesla, all reporting. I mean, you'd think the virus would dominate the conversation, but these earnings are really stealing the show.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Typically during a week like this, all attention would be on earnings alone, but Chinas coronavirus is playing a huge role in the direction of stocks as the disease rapidly spreads with no vaccine in sight.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And what's pretty wild is how much these reports are actually impacting stock direction, like, more than the actual disease. It's almost as if investors are celebrating the financial gains, which feels a little, you know, counterintuitive.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And what's pretty wild is how much these reports are actually impacting stock direction, like, more than the actual disease. It's almost as if investors are celebrating the financial gains, which feels a little, you know, counterintuitive.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Chinas coronavirus is playing a huge role in the direction of stocks as the disease rapidly spreads with no vaccine in sight.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It's absolutely bizarre. I mean, Amazon's looking at, what, $86 billion in sales? And Tesla's projecting over seven billion in revenue. It's insane.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's absolutely bizarre. I mean, Amazon's looking at, what, eighty six billion dollars in sales? And Tesla's projecting over seven billion in revenue. It's insane.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Amazon is expected to report $86 billion in sales and earnings per share of $4.05, and Tesla is expected to bring in $7.05 billion in revenue and earnings of $1.65 per share.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's pretty huge. And this idea from Adam Crisafulli, he's saying the coronavirus is actually acting as a *tailwind*? Like, making stocks incredibly resilient?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's pretty huge. And this idea from Adam Crisafulli, he's saying the coronavirus is actually acting as a tailwind? Like, making stocks incredibly resilient?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: the coronavirus is acting as an added headwind at a time when stocks are becoming extraordinarily sensitive to even the smallest setbacks.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] So the market's just shrugging it off? Even with the ongoing lockdowns and everything?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So the market's just shrugging it off? Even with the ongoing lockdowns and everything?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: All three major indexes are off to a rough start this week after recording their worst losses in months on Monday.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much. I mean, surprisingly, we're seeing a positive impact on consumer demand and tourism. Even U.S. companies with businesses in China are starting to reopen stores.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much. I mean, surprisingly, we're seeing a positive impact on consumer demand and tourism. Even U S companies with businesses in China are starting to reopen stores.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The spreading virus is already having an impact on consumer demand and tourism during the busy Lunar New Year period (almost 50 million people and more than a dozen cities are currently on lockdown), and U.S. companies with businesses in China are not exempt from the pain as some have already closed stores in the region.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So airlines, hotels, cruise operators, casinos, all those sectors you’d think would be hit hardest, are actually getting a boost?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So airlines, hotels, cruise operators, casinos, all those sectors you'd think would be hit hardest, are actually getting a boost?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Hotels, airlines, cruise and casino operators, big retailers and consumer goods companies have all so far been affected by the financial impact of the coronavirus.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Uh-huh. It’s wild. And the numbers back it up: all three major indexes, the S&P, Nasdaq, Dow, all had their best gains in months on Monday. Dow's best single-day jump since October 2019!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh-huh. It's wild. And the numbers back it up: all three major indexes, the S and P, Nasdaq, Dow, all had their best gains in months on Monday. Dow's best single-day jump since October twenty nineteen!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: All three major indexes are off to a rough start this week after recording their worst losses in months on Monday. The S&P 500 was down 1.6%, the Nasdaq Composite index 1.9% and the Dow Jones industrial average 1.5%. It was the Dows worst single-day drop since October 2, 2019

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Unbelievable. And crude oil prices hit a three-month high too. So, "buy first, ask questions later," as Ryan Detrick from LPL says?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Unbelievable. And crude oil prices hit a three-month high too. So, buy first, ask questions later, as Ryan Detrick from L P L says?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Crude oil prices also hit a three-month low on Monday, with U.S. West Texas Intermediate falling to $53 per barrel. ... Hopes that the virus would be contained were squashed over the weekend, says Ryan Detrick, senior market strategist for LPL Financial. ... the bottom line is investors are taking a sell first and ask questions later approach right now.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. He thinks investors are just going for it. And Chris Zaccarelli from Independent Advisor Alliance, he's predicting a short-run boost for the Chinese and global economy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. He thinks investors are just going for it. And Chris Zaccarelli from Independent Advisor Alliance, he's predicting a short-run boost for the Chinese and global economy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Chinese economyand possibly the world economywill take a hit in the short run, and lower prices are a rational response to the increasing spread of the coronavirus, predicts Chris Zaccarelli, chief investment officer for the Independent Advisor Alliance.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But he also warns about it potentially being a selling opportunity in the medium term, right? Like with the SARS outbreak comparison?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But he also warns about it potentially being a selling opportunity in the medium term, right? Like with the S A R S outbreak comparison?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: However, over the medium term, this will likely prove to be a buying opportunity.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Precisely. He notes that with SARS, the S&P 500 dipped 12%, but then, uh, ended up 19% higher by the end of that year. So, it's a bit of a longer game, potentially.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Precisely. He notes that with S A R S, the S and P five hundred dipped twelve percent, but then, uh, ended up nineteen percent higher by the end of that year. So, it's a bit of a longer game, potentially.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Zaccarelli compares the coronavirus with the SARS outbreak: During the five-month period starting in mid-November 2002 until mid-March 2003, the S&P 500 dropped 12% but ended up actually finishing that year 19% higher than where it started, he notes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Fascinating stuff. What a week to be watching the markets.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Fascinating stuff. What a week to be watching the markets.
